div1.p: Curtin writes Cameron about possible patronage appointment.

My letter of yesterday will draw your attention to our conversation in relation to our friend Taggart after election- Taggart found out yesterday just commensing a court by people and engaged--He left in the evening so that I did not see him more than an hour- In the night I looked over his claims and the prospect of getting him the place he aspires to, and became to the conclusion that we cannot get it for him- He will see you about the time this reaches you or I would have written him-

The merchants of Phla will claim the collectorship- My friends in Phla could not be induced to fund his appointment, and I have great doubts if you could control yours He was not as conspicuous in the context as others who will ask for the office, and the knowledge that we have selected him for the last
place in the state will unite all the aspirants and their friends against him-

I write this because I wish to him and will do so with great pleasure but I am so fully convinced that our effort to place him in the collections office will excite a little fight and in disappointment to him and us, that unless satisfied that he can I will not got into it at all

He will not take a of a County--What do you say to the of the Patent office? Anything you incline to believe he can certainly make I will write with you--I submit to your better judgment after you back the matter and write me-
I wish to be frank with Taggart and you will of course communicate to him what I write

closer.seg: P.S. I must go to court and you must understand what I meant by my hasty letter
